front.title: Awareness Protocol v0 (AP0): A Theory and System for the Interpretation and Distribution of Network-Accessible Functionality

abstract.t: Awareness is a network ideology and protocol which attempts to generalize and address the difficulties of API continuity, functionality reuse, and service discovery in internet-connected applications. It proposes a novel architecture of information representation and processing between network-connected services, and defines methodology for computational configuration of relationships between operations on data.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in .

At a high level, Awareness represents sites on the network which contain data-processing capability as End[points, each of which contains one or more Abilities, which provide specialized functionality in the form of inputs and outputs that can be exchanged over the network. Each Endpoint additionally maintains a directory of other Endpoints, and their Abilities, which are accessible for remote use. The entire functionality-distribution network is composed of many such Endpoints, whose Abilities and capabilies for accessing other Abilities are available for use by other Endpoints. The network's overall goal is to collaboratively utilize the communication resources and computational ability of all Endpoints to effectively assemble a processing pathway through multiple Abilities for the solution of a problem.
This document first outlines the reasoning for suggestion of such an architecture, and then proceeds to specify a protocol for its use.

section.title: System Architecture
section.t: This section overviews the structures and units of processing used in Awareness, and describes the features of each and their contribution to the entire functionality-distribution network. This section is intended to provide a high-level overview of the system, and does not specify implementation requirements.

section.title: Data Representation
section.t: This section describes the units of data storage and manipulation whose use is necessary in other parts of the Awareness system.

section.title: Item
section.t: The concept of Awareness is based on a very simple representation of data where each of the multiple parameters comprising a data point is stored as a floating-point value between 0.0 and 1.0, inclusive. A single data point, or item, is an array of one or more of these parameters. A data item's parameters carry meaning by their order, and are implicitly numerically indexed. Data items used for a specific purpose always maintain their parameter content and meaning (the number of parameters nor the parameter order does not change). Data items' parameters have 64-bit (double) precision.

section.title: Set
section.t: It is often necessary to store and manipulate collections of data points, which are known as Sets. A Set provides the structure necessary to encode the input and output of a Function over multiple iterations, and additionally can be used to model a new Function. It consists of two 'streams' of Items - one for input, and one for output. Within one stream, the number of parameters present in each Item contained in the stream must be equal. For example, a Set might have input Items all containing 4 parameters, and output Items all containing 1 parameter. The number of Items contained in all two streams within a Set will be equal.

section.title: Assembly
section.t: An Assembly is used to store data representing a completed pipeline of data processing over the network, which is comprised of uses of the Functions of one or more accessible Endpoints (which refer to other Nodes over the network). It internally specifies the assignments between inputs of each function used and the outputs of the previous one, which are determined optimally for the modeling of a specific Set, by an Algorithm. Thus, each Assembly has a Set for which it is modeled.

section.title: Block Structure
section.t: This section describes the abstractions used in an implementation of Awareness over a network.

section.title: Endpoint
section.t: A Node is a unit of network-connected functionality, which contains variable-length lists of Functions, Endpoints, Algorithms, and Assemblies. It maintains, through its list of Functions, one or more network-accessible operations on data whose implementations are local (e.g. they describe operations which can be carried out without the need for network interaction). Through its list of Endpoints, it maintains knowledge of the other Nodes on the network, which can be asked remotely to provide operations on data through their own local Functions. Its Algorithms each manage a recursive search operation being performed over the Endpoints with which the Node is in contact, and its Assemblies store known pipelines of network-accessible data processing derived from such recursive search operations.

section.title: Ability
section.t: An Ability is representative of one locally-implemented, but network-accessible operation on data. An Ability takes data as input and provides data as output. Each of the two uses of data (input and output) necessary within an Ability is manipulated as an Item with a specific number of parameters. Therefore, a given Ability has a unchanging input data 'size' (number of Item parameters), and an unchanging output data 'size'. An Ability simply allows input data to be exchanged for output data.

section.title: Algorithm
section.t: An Algorithm provides the recursive search method that is described in more detail in the Processing Analysis section. In summary, it is provided with a Set for which a suitable Assembly must be created (that as closely as possible models the inputs and outputs of the Items of the Set), a recursion limit, and a time limit within which the process must be completed. It enacts a search over accessible Endpoints in order to begin, within each, an identical search operation and evaluates the suitability of the results provided (in the form of an Assembly which approximates as closely as possible the input Set) by each.

section.title: Version Byte
section.t: The Version Byte is representative of the version and format of the Awareness protocol in use, and is provided to ensure that integration of future protocol versions will be possible.

The following conditions apply to transmission of the Version Byte:
The Version Byte MUST be equal to 0x00 if Awareness Protocol 0 (AP0) is being implemented.

The following conditions apply to reception of the Version Byte:
If the Version Byte is not found equal to the Version Byte of a supported protocol version, the receiving implementation MUST send an Incompatible PDU.

section.title: Timestamp Integer
section.t: The Timestamp Integer is representative of the point in 'connection time' at which the PDU containing it was assembled. More specifically, it serves as a representation of the time at which the data contained in the PDU containing it was originally created. It is measured in milliseconds. Such a timestamp is included in all Awareness PDUs to facilitate the usage of the protocol for time-sensitive applications.

The following conditions apply to transmission of the Timestamp Integer:
The value encoded in the Timestamp Integer MUST be the time elapsed before the initiation of the TCP connection in milliseconds unless the sending Endpoint is the server, and has previously received an Update Connection Time PDU.

The following conditions apply to reception of the Timestamp Integer:
The value of the Timestamp Integer should be treated as the time at which the data contained in the received PDU was created.

section.title: Unit Type Byte
section.t: The Unit Type Byte is representative of the parsing that should be enacted for the Data Bytes section of the specific PDU in which it occurs. It will also be referred to as describing the "PDU type". This byte contains the primary form of identification for the type of data that is being contained in a PDU, and is used in this document to describe and identify the purpose of the PDU in which it is transmitted.

The following conditions apply to transmission of the Unit Type Byte:
The value of the Unit Type Byte MUST, according to the protocol version specified by the Version Byte, describe correctly the format of the Data Bytes. Any PDU transmitted following the reception of another PDU MUST have its Unit Type byte set to the same value present in the received Requested Response Type Byte.

The following conditions apply to reception of the Unit Type Byte:
The Unit Type Byte MUST be used in determination of the format with which to decode the Data Bytes. Implementations MUST NOT consider PDUs with equivalent Unit Type Bytes compatible if their Version Bytes are not also equivalent. If a Unit Type Byte is received that does not carry a value of a possible PDU type as defined in this specification, a Nonsense Unit PDU MUST be sent.

section.title: Transmission Cause Type Byte
section.t: The Transmission Cause Type Byte is representative of the Unit Type Byte of the Protocol Data Unit that was the cause of the sending of the Protocol Data Unit in which the Transmission Cause Type Byte occurs. The Transmission Cause Type Byte is included in the Awareness PDU as a form of error-checking, in order to increase the reliability of the 'conversation-modeled' form of network communication outlined by the Requested Reponse Type Byte and the Next Requested Response Type Byte.

The following conditions apply to transmission of the Transmission Cause Type Byte:
The Transmission Cause Type Byte MUST be equal to the Unit Type Byte of the PDU to which it responds if the Requested Response Type Byte of the previously received PDU was not equal to 0xFF. If a PDU was previsouly received that had a Requested Response Type Byte equal to 0xFF, the Transmission Cause Type Byte MUST be equal to 0xFF. The Transmission Cause Type Byte MUST carry only values of possible PDU types as described in this specification.

The following conditions apply to reception of the Transmission Cause Type Byte:
The Transmission Cause Type Byte MUST be compared with the Unit Type Byte of the PDU most recently transmitted if the Unit Type Byte of the recently transmitted PDU was not 0xFF, and a Nonsense Unit PDU MUST be sent if the two do not match. In the case that a received Transmission Cause Type Byte carries a value of 0xFF when a PDU with a Requested Response Type Byte not equal to 0xFF was previously sent, a Nonsense Unit PDU MUST be sent.

section.title: Requested Response Type Byte
section.t: The Requested Response Type Byte is representative of the Unit Type Byte of the Protocol Data Unit which the requesting node wishes to receive as a result of its transmission to the receiving node. Along with the Next Requested Response Type Byte, the Requested Response Type Byte provides a conversational, context-aware form of network communication for the Awareness protcol, and is used to initiate a network 'conversation' in the case that it is equal to 0x00, and end a 'conversation' when it is equal to 0x00.

The following conditions apply to transmission of the Requested Response Type Byte:
The Requested Response Type Byte MUST carry only values of possible PDU types that are listed as valid responses to the PDU type in which it occurs. Valid responses to each PDU type are described in the Data Unit Types section. The Requested Response Type Byte MUST be set to 0xFF only if a response is not expected.

The following conditions apply to reception of the Requested Response Type Byte:
If a Requested Response Type Byte is received that does not carry a value of 0xFF, a PDU with a Unit Type Byte equal to the value of the received Requested Response Type Byte MUST be sent in reply.

section.title: Next Requested Response Type Byte
section.t: The Next Requested Response Type Byte specifies the expected value of the Requested Response Type Byte in the PDU sent as a reply to the one in which the Next Requested Response Type Byte occurs. In other words, this byte specifies the PDU type which the sending Node wishes to send next to the receiving Node after it has replied in accordance with the first Requested Response Type Byte. This byte completes the conversational model of communication over the Awareness protocol by allowing the direction of the 'conversation' to be steered according to the network client's intention.

The following conditions apply to transmission of the Next Requested Response Type Byte:
The Next Requested Response Type Byte MUST carry only values of possible PDU types that are listed as valid responses to a PDU of the type specified in the Requested Response Type Byte. The Next Requested Response Type Byte MUST be set to 0xFF in the case that the transmitting Node wishes to receive a PDU in response that has a Requested Response Type Byte equal to 0xFF.

The following conditions apply to reception of the Next Requested Response Type Byte:
The PDU sent in response to a PDU containing a Requested Response Type Byte not equal to 0xFF MUST have its own Requested Response Type Byte set to the value of the Next Requested Response Type Byte in the received PDU.

section.title: Data Length Integer
section.t: The Data Length Integer is a 64-bit unsigned integer representative of the number of bytes to be sent in the following Data Bytes section of the Protocol Data Unit in which it occurs. The Data Length Integer is primarily useful when reading bytes from the Data Bytes section in a protocol implementation, as it can be used to easily determine the number of bytes that should be read.

The following conditions apply to transmission of the Data Length Integer:
The Data Length Integer MUST be a little-endian 64-bit unsigned integer equal to the number of bytes transmitted in the following Data Bytes section of a PDU.

The following conditions apply to reception of the Data Length Integer:
If the value of the Data Length Integer is found not to match a possible length of the Data Bytes section in a possible PDU type, a Nonsesne Data PDU MUST be sent.

section.title: Data Bytes
section.t: The Data Bytes section is a flexible representation of the meaningful information transmitted by a Protocol Data Unit. The format of the Data Bytes (i.e. their meaningful interpretation) is defined by the Data Unit Type Byte.

The following conditions apply to transmission of the Data Bytes:
The Data Bytes MUST be encoded in the format referred to by the value of the Unit Type Byte. The Data Bytes MUST not exceed the value of the Data Length Integer in length.

The following conditions apply to reception of the Data Bytes:
The Data Bytes MUST only be read until their received length is equal to the value of the Data Length Integer. If too few or too many Data Bytes are received, the receiving implementation MUST send a Nonsense Data PDU.

section.title: NothingPDUType
section.t: A Unit Type Byte equal to 0x00 specifies that the PDU in which it is received is of the Nothing type. A Nothing PDU's Data Bytes section contains no data. Often, a Nothing Type PDU will be used as a form of request for another piece of data through the values set in the Requested Response Type Byte and Next Requested REsponse Type Byte.

The following conditions apply to transmission of a Nothing PDU:
The value of the Unit Type Byte MUST be 0x00. The value of the Requested Response Type Byte MUST be 0xFF, 0x00 (Nothing), 0x08 (Item Transfer), 0x09 (Set Transfer), or 0x10 (Assembly Transfer).

The following conditions apply to reception of a Nothing PDU:
A suitable PDU MUST be sent in reply if the Requested Response Type Byte is not 0xFF.

section.title: Local Search
section.t: A Unit Type Byte equal to 0x01 specifies that the PDU in which it is received is of the Local Search type. A Local Search PDU conveys a request for the receiving Node to compute the most optimal Assembly known which models the provided Set. The returned Assembly must use only Functions local to the Node to which the Local Search PDU is sent.

texttable.title: Data Bytes Format for the Local Search PDU

section.t:
The following conditions apply to transmission of a Local Search PDU:
The value of the Unit Type Byte MUST be 0x01. The value of the Requested Response Type Byte MUST be 0x00 (Nothing). In the case that the Requested Response Type Byte is 0x00 (Nothing), the value of the Next Requested Response Type Byte MUST be 0x07 (Assembly Transfer).

The following conditions apply to reception of a Local Search PDU:
The receiving Node MUST enact the Local Search Procedure described in the "Processing Analysis" section of this document.

section.title: Propagating Search
section.t: A Unit Type Byte equal to 0x02 specifies that the PDU in which it is received is of the Propagating Search type. A Propagating Search PDU conveys a request for the receiving Node to compute the most optimal Assembly known which models the provided Set. The returned Assembly may use both Functions local to the node to which the Local Search PDU is sent, and Functions known which are remote to that Node.

section.t:
The following conditions apply to transmission of a Propagating Search PDU:
The value of the Unit Type Byte MUST be 0x02. The value of the Requested Response Type Byte MUST be 0x00 (Nothing). In the case that the value of the Requested Response Type Byte is 0x00 (Nothing), the value of the Next Requested Response Type Byte MUST be 0x07 (Assembly Transfer).

The following conditions apply to reception of a Propagating Search PDU:
The receiving Node MUST enact the Propagating Search Procedure described in the "Processing Analysis" section of this document.
